Looking around the old base at RAF Stanton Harcourt, it was remarkable what was still there - like this nameplate on the guardroom door. I wonder what happened to Sgt. Schofield. For that matter, I wonder what happened to the nameplate when the developers moved in. https://t.co/7i2sO84GnH

@JSArchaeology @wtmworthing 4/x So there’s a possibility that Mr Grundy may have ‘liberated’ that one from a captured pilot or even a pal in another country’s air force.

@JSArchaeology @wtmworthing 3/x… on the same nationality of wrist it started on! There are quite a few Italian watches that ended up on German wrists before being ‘liberated’ on capture (https://t.co/g0j1RYAika)

@JSArchaeology @wtmworthing 2/x …if he had any connection with the Dutch Air Force? Think I’ve read that their pilots used UGs. The RAF issued very few chronographs - the standard was a plain, 3-hander, often Omega/Smiths. The challenge with any “WW2” watch is that it may not have ended up… 2/x
